p: In vitro or preclinical studies have extensively examined the immunomodulatory actions of UCB‐MSCs in RA. UCB‐MSCs exert a profound inhibitory effect on the proliferation, invasive behavior, and inflammatory responses of fibroblast‐like synoviocytes (FLSs) via IL‐10, indoleamine 2,3‐dioxygenase, and transforming growth factor β1. They also suppress T cell activations and induced the generation of Tregs 41. A coculture of FLS with UCB‐MSCs inhibited the expression of pro‐inflammatory cytokines and chemokines IL‐1β, IL‐6, and the chemokine (C‐C motif) ligand‐2; it further induced FLS apoptosis and promoted chondrogenesis 42. hUCB‐MSCs downregulate the secretion of TNF‐α from activated macrophages and also accelerated anti‐inflammatory M2 polarizations in a paracrine manner 12. In overall, hUCB‐MSCs demonstrably correct an immunity imbalance by downregulating the Th1 subset, decreasing the Th17 subset, inducing Tregs, and inhibiting the generation of Tfh cells which attenuate the severity of arthritis comparable to biologic treatments 43.
